description: Bloodborne is the featured game of the 47th installment of Super Replay. Andrew Reiner is the host, with Dan Tack on the sticks. Joining them are Marcus Stewart and special guests John Carson and Lyssa.

external_links.title: Super Replay Is Back With Bloodborne

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Bloodborne Part 1
gameInformerArticle.author: Alex Stadnik
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Yeah, you read that right. Not only is this the day we're jumping back into Replay, but we're also doing it in a big way. Super Replay is back, and we couldn't think of a better last-gen game to kick off the show with than FromSoftware's iconic combination of gameplay excellence and incredible world-building in Bloodborne.

While the esteemed developer was already well-known for its work on the seminal Dark Souls series and paving a way for a new sub-genre, Bloodborne was able to capture the attention and imagination of those not as versed in what From had worked on before. Looking back at the official Game Informer review, it's clear that Bloodborne left an early and lasting mark on those who played it: 

The world of Bloodborne is a dangerous and perilous existence, so who would be fit to take on such a journey? As if you even have to ask? Andrew Reiner and Marcus Stewart are joined by the one and only Dan Tack on the sticks as they kick off their adventure through Yharnam.

We're kicking off the fun at 2 p.m. CT, so be sure to join us in the chat for the start of this amazing journey through one of the best Souls titles on the planet. If you can't get enough of our live shows, remember to subscribe on YouTube, Twitch, Twitter, and Facebook to get notified when we go live each week!

description: God Hand is the featured game of the 45th installment of Super Replay. Beginning with Episode 7 a second game; Asura's Wrath, was added to the Super Replay. This marks the first time since Resident Evil a Super Replay featured two games. Andrew Reiner is the host, with Joe Juba on the sticks. Joining them are Ben Reeves and Leo Vader.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – God Hand Episode 20: The M.A.J.O.R. and the Minor: Part 2
gameInformerArticle.author: Andrew Reiner
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
After a festive holiday season, Game Informer's annual 12.31 Super Replay usually brings suffering. In years past, this day has kicked off complete playthroughs of stinkers like Overblood, Overblood 2, Blue Stinger, Illbleed, Raw Danger, Martian Gothic: Unification, Sonic the Hedgehog, and Vampire Hunter D.

Figuring out which game will be honored with this spot is a stressful decision that usually takes a full year to figure out. That wasn't the case this year. The community figured it out for us. We had the somewhat official I Watched the Entire Overblood Super Replay group vote for a Super Replay earlier this year. With hundreds of votes cast, the poll ended in a tie between Killer 7 and God Hand. Rather than just flipping a coin to see which one we would do, I decided to record both of them. We knocked out Killer 7 earlier this year, and almost rolled right into God Hand, but couldn't find a window to get it done in a productive way. I shelved the Super Replay until 12.31. It was one of the games I was considering years ago for this spot anyway.

Now it's here, and I think the community made the right choice. This game is absolutely bonkers and is a sheer delight to take in. God Hand was created by Clover Studio for Capcom and released in America on October 10, 2006 exclusively for PlayStation 2. Enjoy the Super Replay. I know it was a long time coming. We haven't produced as many as we have in the past, but it isn't because we are slacking off. The recording of the Game Informer Show takes up considerable studio and editor time, and we just haven't had the window to crank the out like we used to. I'd like to say we'll try to do more in the future, but I'm always thinking that, and the stars just haven't aligned.

You can watch the latest episode up above, or click the arrows along the side of the video to start from the beginning! To watch the full series, click here to find it on YouTube.

description: Mega Man is the featured game in the 44th installment of Super Replay. Andrew Reiner is the host, and on the sticks is special guest Tim Turi. Joining them are Jeff Cork and Leo Vader.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Mega Man
gameInformerArticle.author: Andrew Reiner
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Capcom's Tim Turi joins the Game Informer crew for a brief (but complete) look at Mega Man's first adventure. We all know Tim has proven himself as a great gamer, somehow managing to work his way through Overblood, Illbleed, and the atrocious Martian Gothic, but he needed a little help getting through Mega Man. He uses a new rewind power to undo his deaths. This functionality is a part of the recently released Mega Man Legacy Collection, which you can play on Switch, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One.

Tim does a bang up job working his way through these difficult stages, and more impressively, remembering which weapons work on which bosses. We hope you enjoy this short Super Replay, and come back in a few weeks to check out the first episode of our complete playthrough of God Hand.

description: The first and only episode of the Mega Man Super Replay, with special guest Tim Turi from Capcom.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Mega Man
youtubeVideo.description: Special guest Tim Turi joins Reiner, Cork and Leo for a rewind-abusing playthrough of the original Mega Man, played on Switch in the Mega Man Legacy Collection II.

description: Killer7 is the featured game in the 43rd installment of Super Replay. Andrew Reiner is the host, and on the sticks is Suriel Vazquez, who ranks Killer7 as his favorite game of all time. Joining them are Joe Juba and Leo Vader. Ben Hanson fills in for Leo in Episode 4. Jeff Cork fills in for Reiner in Episode 8. Special guest Goichi Suda joins the crew on a bonus episode.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Bonus Episode Featuing Suda51
gameInformerArticle.author: Suriel Vazquez
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
At the end of our Replay Civil War, it all came down to you to choose the next Super Replay! Our Overblood Facebook group ended up choosing two games through a tie: Killer7 and Godhand.

You chose well. Killer7 is my favorite game of all time, for reasons I will fully elaborate on in the near future. The short version, however, it's that it's the closest video games have gotten to being a David Lynch film. It benefits from being played alone in near silence, so you can fully process its wild, surreal moments, cool characters, and ambiguous plot.

In fitting with its themes, we decided to take Killer7 very seriously, as Andrew Reiner, Joe Juba, Leo Vader, and I focus only an the artistry of Killer7 and never talk about anything else and make absolutely zero jokes. Enjoy!

description: The first episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "What's On That Shirt?"

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 1: What's On That Shirt?
youtubeVideo.description: Today we begin our descent into madness. Joe, Reiner and Leo join Suriel for a look at his favorite game of all time, the bizarre and unsettling Killer7. Will the gang be able to stay sane throughout the adventure? Or will they be spouting complete nonsense to each other within the first ten minutes of the first episode?

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 2: A Personal Joe Juba
youtubeVideo.description: Our GI Think Tank reconvenes to ponder new, important questions: What's a better name for zombies? Where you would you put Joe Juba's face on your body? Which famous person would you let eat you? Learn all these answers and more as we dive deeper into the twisted world of Killer7.

description: The thirteenth and final regular episode of the Killer7 Super Replay is titled "Finale". A bonus episode replaying the first part of the game with writer and director, Suda51, was announced at the start of the episode.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Ep 13: Finale
youtubeVideo.description:
The story of Killer7 comes to a thrilling conclusion as we define madsturbating, ask why someone would eat a 3 Musketeers bar, and take on Greg Nightmare.

Tune in at the same time next week for one more bonus episode with special guest Suda 51!

description: This bonus episode of the Killer7 Super Replay features writer and director, SUDA51 (aka Goichi Suda).

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Killer7 Bonus Episode With Suda51
youtubeVideo.description:
We're as surprised as you are, but it really happened. Head of Grasshopper Manufacture Inc. Goichi Suda, also known as Suda51 is here to help us close out our Super Replay of Killer7. Join us for rare insights into the development of Killer7, and see how he answers some of the tough questions and hypotheticals we posed to each other throughout our playthrough.

Much of the time spent translating has been cut for a more succinct video.

description: Vampire Hunter D is the featured game of the 42nd installment of Super Replay. It is the eighth 12/31 Super Replay.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Finale
gameInformerArticle.author: Andrew Reiner
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Our playthrough of Sonic the Hedgehog 2006 is the most successful Super Replay to date. One thing became abundantly clear: You love watching us suffer while playing broken games. From the comments I read, a good number of you expected we would play another Sonic game for the annual 12.31 Super Replay. As tempting as that idea was, we decided to flip the script again, and do something completely different. Playing a survival horror game without Tim Turi still feels wrong. Playing another Sonic game just feels wrong, period. So we decided to turn our sights on the anime crowd, a pocket of loyal fans Replay hasn't mocked enough.

The one game that bubbled to the surface was Vampire Hunter D, a little-known PlayStation relic that launched on September 25, 2000. Developed by Victor Interactive Software and published by Jaleco, Vampire Hunter D is a game about a powerful talking hand that is attached to a vampire. I don't want to give away much more than that. The only other thing I will say is, we're having a terrible good time playing it. As always, we hope you enjoy this year's pick. It's unexpected, I know, but that's how these 12.31 Super Replays should be.

Episode 5

Apologies for audio issues this episode, cutscene audio has been restored but the rest of the episode just has music from the game.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 1
youtubeVideo.description: Happy 12/31 everyone! The year-long wait until the next 12/31 Super Replay is over, and now we can finally start playing our next exciting title from yesteryear. This time it's Vampire Hunter D, the game based on an anime that Kyle likes. Tune in next week for another terrifying episode!

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 2
youtubeVideo.description: After a deadly mistake is made, Reeves assumes the leadership role and does his best to navigate Reiner, Kyle and Leo through the twisted catacombs of the castle.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 3
youtubeVideo.description: The gang's horrifying adventures continue as they endure their most difficult challenges yet en route to recover the elusive "wrench."

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 4
youtubeVideo.description: The changes in leadership continue as we enter our darkest episode yet, with a special appearance from Leo's friend Donnie.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 5
youtubeVideo.description:
On a very special episode of the Vampire Hunter D Super Replay, tragedy strikes the Vampire Hunter D family and they work together to try and pick up the pieces.
And in an even greater tragedy, we lost the game audio. Cutscene audio has been restored but the rest of the episode just has music from the game. Our apologies.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 6
youtubeVideo.description: The gang is working together like a well-oiled machine as Reeves, Kyle and Leo talk about Taco Bell and cartoons while Reiner actually focuses on the game and makes progress. A good Super Replay is all about teamwork.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 7
youtubeVideo.description: Reiner faces some of his most difficult physical challenges yet, while the gang focuses on the intellectual challenges, such as: why are manholes called that? Who was the best character on LOST? What happened to Donnie the Morguetician? All these answers and more in this week's exciting episode.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Episode 8
youtubeVideo.description: Our story races towards a climactic finish as the gang collects plates, fights bosses, and finally gets some answers about Donnie the Morguetician's fatal car accident.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay – Vampire Hunter D Finale
youtubeVideo.description: The journey of everyone's favorite Dunpeal finally comes to a close in the final episode of our Vampire Hunter D Super Replay. Reiner faces off against the toughest bosses the game has to offer and we say our goodbyes to the friends we made throughout our nine hour tour of the castle.

description: Ape Escape is the featured game of the 41st installment of Super Replay. It is the first live Super Replay, airing on December 1, 2017 starting at 8 am central time. Long asked for by the Facebook Group, it was the reward for reaching the Extra Life 2017 goal.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Ape Escape
gameInformerArticle.author: Andrew Reiner
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Our community recently raised over $60,000 for Children's Miracle Network Hospitals through our 25-hour Extra Life livestream. As a big "thank you" for donating so much, we decided to give the community something they've wanted for years: a Super Replay of Ape Escape! This Super Replay is also special since we recorded the entire thing live and in one, fun sitting! Check out the full archive of the stream below and let us know what you think of the live format in the comments below.

Thanks again for donating during Extra Life, and we hope you all enjoy the legendary Ape Escape Super Replay!

description: The Super Replay for Ape Escape began and ended on December 1, 2017 and ran for one live episode. Super Replays of God Hand and Killer7 were announced at the end of this episode, the result of a tied poll on the OverBlood Facebook Group.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay - Ape Escape
youtubeVideo.description: Join the Game Informer crew for the first ever LIVE Super Replay! We're playing all the way through Ape Escape in one sitting. God help us all.

description: Star Fox 2 is the featured game of the 40th installment of Super Replay. The game was developed for the Super NES, but was released for the first time in 2017 with the Super NES Classic Edition. This Super Replay was technically released the day before the game itself released!
Comprised of only one 40-minute episode, this is the shortest "official" Super Replay to date.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Star Fox 2
gameInformerArticle.author: Ben Reeves
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
In 1995, Nintendo was set to release a sequel to the hit on-rails shooter, Star Fox. This new adventure introduced several new characters, randomly generated stages, and an ever-changing strategy map component. Star Fox 2 was nearly complete before Nintendo pulled it from the release calendar...or was it? We'll let you decide.

Thanks to the SNES Classic, players can now check out this lost game. Join Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Ben Reeves, and Leo Vader as they travel the galaxy and shove their Arwing blasters down Andross' throat, saving the universe once again.

description: The Super Replay for Star Fox 2 begins and ends with Andrew Reiner as host and features Jeff Cork and Ben Reeves.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay - Star Fox 2
youtubeVideo.description:
Join Ben Reeves, Jeff Cork, and Leo Vader to witness Andrew Reiner's potentially record-setting speed run of Star Fox 2, until it inevitably gets smashed when the SNES Classic releases worldwide on September 29th. And come on back tomorrow night at 8 PM Central for your regularly scheduled episode of Replay!

For more on Starfox 2, check out the inside story on the rocky road to release on our website: http://www.gameinformer.com/b/features/archive/2017/09/27/the-inside-story-on-the-star-fox-sequel-that-took-more-than-20-years-to-release.aspx

description: Pokémon Snap is the featured game of the thirty-ninth installment of Super Replay. Previously a Replay, it was used in the final round in the Super Replay Showdown.

The game features 63 of the original generation of 151 Pokémon. It features 6 main sections (Beach, Tunnel, Volcano, River, Cave and Valley) and a bonus level (Rainbow Isle). The controller is passed between hosts Andrew Reiner and Kyle Hilliard per stage as they compete for the highest photo score.

The nightmarish Sonic the Hedgehog preceded this Super Replay. The emotional strain of it apparently necessitated an extended break from new games in the Super Replay series. This led to the latest start for a new Super Replay in a calendar year, with the first episode airing on July 31.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Pokémon Snap Episode 5
gameInformerArticle.author: Kyle Hilliard
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
After the marathon that was Shenmue II, Andrew Reiner and I decided it was time to play something that didn't require quite so much long-term commitment. We wanted something that felt closer to a walk in the park, or a leisurely ride through a park, which is how we landed on Pokémon Snap. The Nintendo 64 favorite offered Pokémon fans their first look at their favorite creatures in 3D and, for our purposes, doesn't tell an elongated story about revenge.

Despite our intentions to play something a little less intense, we still want to make sure we get a photo of every Pokémon in the game. We will also be passing the sticks in order to foster some competition. At the end of every episode we will make sure to check and see who took the best photo.

Enjoy the episodes, and leave comments! We plan on reading them out loud during the episodes just like we did with our last few two-person Super Replays.

description: The Super Replay for Pokémon Snap concludes with the fifth episode. Andrew Reiner and Kyle Hilliard both remain on, swapping after each run.

pok\u00e9mon_captured_this_episode: For overall scores visit the main page.

The main focus of this episode were signs. Reiner captures Mewtwo in the first Cave run. Despite two hit and runs Kyle was able to capture Kingler in his Beach run. Little focus was put on photos leading to low overall scores throughout the episode. The next run to capture the Tunnel Pinsir sign saw Reiner get it on the vehicular bloodlust and attack an Electabuzz. Kyle quickly captures the Volcano Koffing sign in the following run. Reiner rushes through the River level and misses his sign but is allowed the Super Replay's first restart. The rough start mulligan pays off and the Cubone sign is captured. The final Valley level sees an immediate Dugtrio sign capture by Kyle unlocking the final level; Rainbow Cloud. The episode closes with Reiner capturing the Super Replay's highest score: an 8,500 point Mew.

description: Sonic the Hedgehog is the featured game for the 38th installment of Super Replay, continuing the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games. This is the first 12/31 Super Replay without Tim Turi, so it's a departure from the survival horror games that are typically played on 12/31. This can be seen as a new beginning for the 12/31 Super Replay - moving on from OverBlood and games of its ilk, and expanding the definition of "bad" Super Replay games.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – The Worst Sonic The Hedgehog Ever
gameInformerArticle.author: Andrew Reiner
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
When I decided to turn the 12.31 Super Replay into an annual event, I knew the focus needed to be on bad games. People enjoyed watching us suffer; that was the hook that stood out. We used Overblood as the foundation for the type of game we were looking for each year. Blue Stinger, Illbleed, And Martian Gothic were all games that delivered a similar stench. They were perfect selections for the annual Super Replay.

When Tim Turi left Game Informer to work at Capcom, I realized this Super Replay event wouldn't be the same without him. He played through all of these bad games, and, well, I don't think it would have been fair to continue on without him. Out of respect to Tim, we are moving away from the survival-horror angle, and are falling back on my original pitch: it needs to be a bad game period.

As it turns out, there are many different flavors of terrible video games, and I think we found another example in Sonic the Hedgehog that is every bit as enjoyable, campy, and unbearably bad as the original Overblood. The game is simply titled Sonic the Hedgehog, but it's often referred to as Sonic '06. It's developed by Sonic Team for Xbox 360 and PlayStation 3, and is another failed attempt to give the blue speedster new life.

The game is as bad as they come, and it won't take long for you to see why. It's an abomination of platforming and action, and the story also makes it look like two wildly different games were mashed together into one.

New episodes of this Super Replay will hit every Tuesday and Sunday on Game Informer and YouTube. I don't like to blow smoke, but I truly think this is one of our best Super Replays yet, perhaps because it's a new beginning and a different kind of awful. Enjoy!

For more episodes of Replay, check out our Replay hub, or click on the banner below to watch episodes on YouTube.

description: The first episode of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay has Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, and Ben Reeves at the controls, with guest Joe Juba.

in_this_episode: Intro Cutscene: We start off watching the introduction, which introduces our main characters, Princess Elise (not to be confused with Elise Favis), Dr. Eggman, and our hero Sonic the Hedgehog. We also see a mysterious "white Sonic". Reiner tells us that Elise and Sonic will be making out in this game, so stay tuned. This intro cutscene reminds Kyle of Final Fantasy Kingsglaive.

Soleanna: Gameplay starts off in the open-world city of Soleanna. Here, they test out some shoes from Alberto Robert, in a mission called "The winder of a Shoemaker" (??). These shoes allow Sonic to enter the first level, Wave Ocean.

Wave Ocean: Sonic collects a bunch of rings, and rides a whale. Then Tails starts to shut the gate, to block the whale, but it only goes halfway down. The whale, however, gets the idea and backs off. During this level, we learn that Joe Juba never walks down hallways, on principle. What a weird guy.
Soleanna: Back to the city. Here we discover Sonic's alter ego, Sonic the Hedgehole (or Sonic the Asshole), who takes a soccer ball from a group of kids and kicks it into the ocean. What a jerk!

Boss Fight: Egg-Cerberus: Kyle finds himself getting emotionally attached to this giant creature, comparing it to The Last Guardian. However, it must be killed to continue with the story, so Kyle reluctantly "grinds the tail" and eventually slays it.

Dusty Desert: After some hilarious deaths, falling through the sand at high speeds, they discover how to get past it, and finish this mostly uneventful level. At the end, we're treated to a cutscene of Sonic and Elise slowly falling in love. Then Sonic forces her to run at an insane speed, almost tearing her arm off in the process. This episode ends with the dramatic reveal of Silver the Hedgehog, who vows to destroy Sonic for some reason.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay - Sonic The Hedgehog: Episode 1
youtubeVideo.description: Join Andrew Reiner and crew on this adventure into the borderline unplayable Sonic The Hedgehog from 2006. New episodes every Sunday and Tuesday!

description: The second episode of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay has Ben Reeves, Andrew Reiner, and Joe Juba at the controls, with guest Kyle Hilliard.

in_this_episode: Boss Fight: Silver the Hedgehog: This is an absolute disaster. Silver keeps freezing Sonic in midair whenever he gets close, killing Sonic without any chance to fight back. They quickly look up a walkthrough and figure out the strategy. It's still terrible, but they manage to defeat him. Silver says that the Iblis Trigger must be destroyed, whatever that means. Amy is introduced. She holds off Silver, while Sonic goes after Elise.

Soleanna: Sonic decides to fight the Soleanna Boys, a group of little kids. Joe reveals that he has no problem beating up children in real life, as a grown man. What a weird guy. Sonic finds Pele, the Beloved Dog, and has to walk very slowly, which is a whole lot of fun. Sonic the Hedgehole breaks up a tea party with four identically dressed men, by attacking the men then running off. The soldiers in the city then put together a logic puzzle for Sonic to see if he is worthy. Okay guys. Then Sonic needs to find Knuckles for some reason. In the process, he gets a disk for some guy, with classified info on it, by "destroying all enemies in the New City". The crew discusses their plans for the Game Informer floating car, based on Joe's designs from 3rd grade. Joe is now Senior Magnetics Engineer. Sonic kills a bunch of robots, while the crew discusses Sonic the Hedgehole's favorite drink, Bag O' Blue Nuts. This is a hot, lumpy drink that comes in a bag, similar to Ben Reeves' favorite beverage, warmed-up old bowls of Rice Krispies. We find Knuckles, which is when Wade Wojcik chimes in to tell us that echidnas (like Knuckles) have a four-headed penis. He gets this information from penile scientist Dick Cocks. Thanks Wade.
White Acropolis: A terrible snowboarding level. This ends in failure, sending them back to a WAY earlier checkpoint to end the episode.

youtubeVideo.title: Super Replay - Sonic The Hedgehog: Episode 2
youtubeVideo.description: Join Andrew Reiner and crew on this adventure into the borderline unplayable Sonic The Hedgehog from 2006. New episodes every Sunday and Tuesday!

description: The third episode of the Sonic the Hedgehog Super Replay has Andrew Reiner, Kyle Hilliard, Joe Juba, and Ben Reeves at the controls.

in_this_episode: White Acropolis: Continues with the snowboarding from last time. We learn that Reiner farts when pressing buttons really hard. We also learn that Brian Shea is the densest and whitest material on Earth (with snow taking second place in both categories). Joe Juba, GI's resident snowman (because he knows a lot about snow and men), gets in a plug for his Sonic fan art, which reveals the color of Sonic's penis. What a weird guy.

Crisis City: We see a cutscene, in which Reiner admires Eggman's legs, and Sonic and friends are sent to the distant future. There they meet Shadow and Rouge. Then the level starts, with fire everywhere and raining cars. Reiner calls this level the biggest pile of Shea he has ever seen. Here, Ben Reeves reveals a few "Ben-ventions":
Pogrow Sticks - like pogo sticks that are also Chia pets
Ear Pugs - ear plugs that look like pugs
Garden Garb - a shirt you wear that has plants growing on it
After failing this level a few times (the final time, Sonic just kills himself before they even gain control), they decide to switch to Silver's episode for a while.

Crisis City (Silver Episode): Silver has telekinesis, so there's a lot of throwing cars and stuff here. Blaze is with him. He's going after Iblis, the Flames of Disaster. The episode ends right before the boss fight with Iblis.

description: Shenmue II is the featured game in the thirty-seventh installment of Super Replay. It premiered on Oct 1, 2016. It was created by Sega AM2 the developers of the thirtieth Super Replay installment, Shenmue.

gameInformerArticle.title: Never Played Shenmue II? Watch Us Super Replay The Whole Thing
gameInformerArticle.author: Kyle Hilliard
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Last year, over the course of four months, we played through Shenmue for the Dreamcast in its entirety. It was an experimental video series, with an undefined schedule that allowed us to take in all the feedback for each episode by reading and responding to comments in (almost) real time. The experiment was a success! So we immediately decided (after playing through Dark Souls III, Tex Murphy: Under A Killing Moon, Shadow of the Colossus, and Resident Evil 4) that there was no time like the present to return to Yu Suzuki's masterpiece. For the sequel, we're playing the Xbox version that was published by Microsoft in 2002.

In the first episode we explore the city a little bit, make a friend with a fellow capsule toy collector, and get all our stuff stolen. There's also a lady who forgot to finish getting dressed who really likes her motorcycle. In episode two, we make some progress by giving a hungry guy who loves naps some money, and getting a job that's almost as cool as being a forklift driver. We punch a tree in episode three. In episode four we break a rock with our hand because a homeless porcupine asked us to. In episode five we follow a lady to her apartment in the middle of the day and sleep on her couch. In episode 6 we look for a book. Spoiler alert: we don't find it. In episode seven we calm our revenge nerves by catching some leaves, you know, as one does. In episode eight, we pursue duck races with every ounce of our being. In episode nine, we attend a Fight Club. In episode 10 we achieve something amazing. In episode 11 we punch a tree so hard a duck falls out. In episode 12, we get back to the actual game. I don't remember what we did in episode 13, but I am sure it is entertaining. In episode 14 we fight a caveman for way too long. In episode 15 we spend all the money we spent episode 14 trying to earn. In episode 16, we go to Kowloon and act out that one scene from Once Upon a Time In Mexico. In episode 17, we look through all the drawers in someone's apartment for some reason. In episode 18 we learn that Kowloon apparently has the economy to support 5,978 separate bird stores. In episode 19 we walk on a board instead of using the stairs like a pair of fools. In episode 20 we have to show off our skills to Oddjob, for some reason. In episode 21, we have to make some money, or we don't get to play anymore. So we did. Twice. In episode 22, we meet our favorite character – the butterfly brawler. In episode 23 we complain about complicated elevators and learn where Shiegeru Miyamoto got that whole thumbs-up, thumbs-down thing from. In episode 24 we make a surprising amount of progress and throw a bucket of trash on a mean lady. In episode 25, Kyle gets real upset about sleeves for some reason. In episode 26 we do a whole lot of walking and a whole lot of talking. We do a whole lot of walking and a whole lot of talking in episode 27 and episode 28. In episode 29 we discover a revelation and watch the credits roll!

Stay tuned for more episodes at some point, and leave us lots of comments! We'll probably read yours on the next episode.

For more episodes of Replay, check out our Replay hub, or click on the banner below to watch episodes on YouTube.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Resident Evil 4
gameInformerArticle.author: Kyle Hilliard
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Much like the zombie creatures Resident Evil is known for, we can't seem to rid ourselves of former Game Informer editor turned Capcom associate brand manager, Tim Turi. He tries to leave and we think he's gone, but suddenly he, and his unquenchable desire to play Resident Evil while others watch, comes back to life.

We embrace this kind of reanimation though, and were happy to make Tim play through Resident Evil 4 in its entirety in order to remind everyone that that game has found yet another set of platforms on which to exist – the Xbox One and PlayStation 4.

Join us as we reminisce about one of the best games on GameCube (and later PlayStation 2, then PC, then Wii, then Zeebo then Xbox 360, then PlayStation 3, and then iOS and Android), pressure Tim to tell us more about Resident Evil 7, and bring in different editors to push against the Los Ganados threat. The full playthrough can be found at the bottom of the page or on our YouTube channel.

For more Resident Evil Super Replays, follow the links for the series where we played the original Resident Evil and the remake simultaneously, Resident Evil 2, Resident Evil: Code Veronica with special guest Capcom's Brett Elston, and finally the tangentially related Mega Man Legends 2 with guest Capcom's Greg Moore. We like playing Capcom games with Capcom people.

For more episodes of Replay and Super Replay, check out our Replay hub, or click on the banner below to watch episodes on YouTube.

Super Replay: Shadow of the Colossus

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Shadow Of The Colossus
gameInformerArticle.author: Kyle Hilliard
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Team Ico's latest, The Last Guardian, is finally (pending any additional surprise delays) arriving this October, which is a perfect excuse to play through Shadow of the Colossus in its entirety.

Of course, you don't really need an excuse to play Shadow of the Colossus because it is a fantastic game. Join myself and Andrew Reiner as we relive some of our Shenmue magic by keeping this a two-person show, making our way through the game's strange world and bringing down its imposing beasts. We don't have a strict schedule in mind for this series, because we want to be able to absorb everyone's feedback episode to episode, so we likely won't be recording multiple episodes in advance. We're all going on this journey together, so please sound off in the comments section below or on YouTube.

For more Super Replay, follow the links to find our full playthroughs of Shenmue and Tex Murphy: Under A Killing Moon. You can also see our full playthrough of Dark Souls III here, which technically isn't a Super Replay, but is pretty close. For our Replay of Shadow of the Colossus, head here.

For more episodes of Replay, check out our Replay hub, or click on the banner below to watch episodes on YouTube.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Tex Murphy: Under A Killing Moon
gameInformerArticle.author: Javy Gwaltney
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
A few months ago I emerged as the victor of Game Informer's most recent Super Replay Showdown. My prize? Subjecting my fellow editors and our viewers to the strange and maddening FMV adventure game that is Tex Murphy: Under A Killing Moon. Starring a bumbling private eye who spends his weeks trying to make rent and ends up going on a quest to prevent the end of the world, Under A Killing Moon is a peculiar mishmash of genres, the kind of game that could have only been birthed in the early '90s.

It's pure, undistilled zaniness that has to been seen to be believed. So sit back in your chair and push the Maltese falcon on your desk out of the way of the screen so you can join me, Andrew Reiner, Dan Tack, and Kyle Hilliard as we navigate this twisted, futuristic vision of San Francisco, putting our flimsy detective skills to use while being constantly berated by James Earl Jones.

For more episodes of Replay, check out our Replay hub, or click on the banner below to watch episodes on YouTube.

description: Martian Gothic: Unification is the featured game of the thirty-third installment of Super Replay. It continues the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games. It is the last 12/31 Super Replay to feature Tim Turi and the last to fit the survival horror theme.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Martian Gothic: Unification (Part Sixteen)
gameInformerArticle.author: Jeff Cork
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Update: Benevolent Replay fan, Brian, has rescued us from ridiculous map of Martian Gothic's Vita Base. Brian used our Super Replay footage to meticulously recreate Vita Base with an easier-to-follow overhead perspective. The map is a huge improvement over the garbage in-game map. You can download Brian's map yourself at the bottom of this article and follow along.

Remember what you were doing back in February 2011? We do. During our Ape Escape episode of Replay, we played a game for our Roulette segment called Martian Gothic: Unification. As Tim learned, it leaned toward the survival horrible end of the survival-horror spectrum, making it a great Super Replay candidate. Four years later, we're heading back to the red planet to see what kind of nightmarish challenges await.

If you've ever played a clunky PS1-era horror game and thought, "I wish I could juggle three characters and their inventory, in addition to these terrible controls," you have a good idea of what Martian Gothic has to offer. That's not counting the game's unique take on voice acting and characterization. Join us as we do our best to play through the game, limited save slots permitting. We have faith.

Part Sixteen:

Want more Replay? Check out our hub to catch up on all our previous episodes by clicking the banner below.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Beyond Good & Evil (Part Twelve)
gameInformerArticle.author: Andrew Reiner
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
One of the most criminally overlooked games from yesteryear, Beyond Good & Evil is a story-driven adventure that follows a photojournalist named Jade and her mechanic friend Pey'j. We won't spoil where this journey goes, but fans of Zelda, Pokémon Snap, and fun science fiction stories should either watch our playthrough or pick up the game and play it. This is an exceptional game from developer Ubisoft Montpellier and legendary creator Michel Ancel.

Beyond Good & Evil was originally released for PlayStation 2, Xbox, GameCube, and PC on November 11, 2003, but to make it look better on your massive displays, we're playing the HD re-release from 2011, which we downloaded through Xbox One's snazzy, new backwards compatibility.

Unlike other Super Replays, we're airing these episodes as soon as we finish them, and we won't record more until you've watched and commented on the newest chapter. We want you the viewer to be a part of this journey as well. We plan to read as many comments as we can during the next episode. If you have any questions for us about Beyond Good & Evil, Replay, or video games in general, list them in the comments section below, or on YouTube. If all goes as planned, we'll finish this Super Replay in December, and will roll into our annual 12.31 Super Replay next. Thanks again for the support!

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Dark Souls & Artorias Of The Abyss DLC
gameInformerArticle.author: Tim Turi
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
From Software is on a roll. Bloodborne is one of the biggest Game of the Year contenders for 2015, and Dark Souls III is one of the most-anticipated games of 2016. We're so excited for Dark Souls III that we traveled to From Software's studio in Tokyo, Japan to have an in-depth interview with series creator Hidetaka Miyazaki and play more of the game for our October Dark Souls III cover story. Well, the excitement crackling around From Software's Souls series is too much for us to handle, so we couldn't stop ourselves from playing through the entire the first Dark Souls game.

This isn't Dan Tack and Tim Turi's first From Software rodeo, either. The duo has tackled Dark Souls II in a previous Chronicles series and played hours of Bloodborne together. So sit back, relax next to your nearest kindled bonfire, and watch the excitement unfold as Dan guides Tim through his first full playthrough of Dark Souls until the final foe is vanquished.

Start from the beginning with the video gallery below or watch and share all the videos on YouTube.

Click on the banner below to visit our Dark Souls III hub and follow our coverage.

description: Shenmue is the featured game of the thirtieth installment of Super Replay. Originally a Chronicles episodes, it was upgraded to a Super Replay after fan encouragement to finish the game. It's sequel Shenmue II went on to be the thirty-seventh Super Replay.

gameInformerArticle.title: Shenmue Super Replay
gameInformerArticle.author: Andrew Reiner
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Update: Now that our playthrough of Shenmue is complete, we're moving it from the Chronicles video section to Super Replay.

With Shenmue 3's Kickstarter officially funded, numerous people in Game Informer's community sent in requests for complete Super Replay playthroughs of the first two games in the Shenmue series. Several Game Informer staffers also expressed interest in either revisiting this series or seeing it for the first time. Since we already have numerous Super Replay projects in the works, yet wanted to get a Shenmue playthrough going now, we decided to record it as a crowd-driven experiment of sorts. If you like what you see, and want more of it, we'll return with more episodes. Just let us know in the comments section below or on YouTube.

In the first episode, I join Kyle Hillard for his first hands-on experience with Shenmue. We play through the first hour of this adventure, purchase several capsule toys along the way, and turn down myriad requests from children to play an assortment of sports. In episode two, we continue or journey to find the men in black suits in the black car, track down the arcade, and purchase even more capsule toys. In episode three, we get our first successful taste of QTEs. In episode four, we punch an arcade machine. In episode five, we wake a sleeping man in a tattoo parlor, and steal from our roommate. In episode six, things get emotional and we spend way too much time dialing a rotary phone. Episode seven serves as a masterclass in how to play Shenmue, showcasing a perfect run without any glaring mistakes or missteps. In episode eight, we jam a sword into a wall and act like it's not a big deal. In episode nine we continue exploring our dad's weird hidden treasure cave and meet Santa Claus. In episode 10 we question whether or not we should be trusted with Fuku-san's life savings. In episode 11, we punch Dead or Alive creator Tomonobu Itagaki. In episode 12, we battle Gollum from Lord of the Rings, and craft a special outro that makes it worth sticking around until the very end of the video. In episode 13, we get a job. In episode 14, we work that job. In episode 15, we continue to work that job. And fight some dudes. In episode 16, we show that maybe we do actually know how to fight, but unfortunately a computer crash caused the last few minutes of video to not be captured – so you will just have to take our word for it. Episode 17 showcases another hard day's work, and finally some luck with the capsule toy machine. In episode 18, our pal Goro gives us some surprising news. Episode 19 is a short one, but a lot happens and there is a musical motorcycle interlude. In episode 20, we complete the game.

Unlike our Replay look at this game, we have one big rule in place: No talking over the cutscenes. We're engaged with the story, and are willing to do as much side content as you want to see. Again, just be vocal, and let us know what you think of the show!

title: Super Replay: Michigan: Report from Hell

external_links.title: Super Replay: Michigan: Report from Hell
Super Replay: Michigan: Report From Hell

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Michigan: Report From Hell
gameInformerArticle.author: Jeff Cork
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Grasshopper Manufacture has a long history of developing oddball games. Before there was Shadows of the Damned, No More Heroes, and Killer7, the studio made a little something called Michigan: Report from Hell. It was never released in the U.S., in spite of being localized for Europe and Australia. Did players over here miss out? You'll have to watch...

Join Tim, Reiner, Joe, and me as we learn about what it's like to be a TV-news cameraman during a monster outbreak. Apparently, part of the job is to keep both hands on the camera, no matter what – you can forget about opening doors. To make matters worse, your audio guy insists on making himself (and his boom mic) part of the story. Fortunately, Tim found a wonderful way to release a little steam, which he does again and again and again and again.

Enjoy!

For more episodes of Replay, visit our hub below.

description: Raw Danger is the featured game of the twenty-seventh installment of Super Replay. It continues the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games. It is the penultimate 12/31 Super Replay to feature Tim Turi and fit the survival horror theme.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Raw Danger Episode 12
gameInformerArticle.author: Wade Wojcik
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Another great year of Replay is at an end. We played plenty of good games, more bad games than we should have, said goodbye to dear friends, and opened the door for new ones (like me and another you'll meet in the new year.) The year ahead is loaded with surprises, including the much talked-about Replay: Season 3, something I've been working closely with Reiner on since I started.

But before we get there, we're inviting you to our annual event: the 12/31/14 Super Replay. Holding true to recent traditions, we picked a game that takes place around the holidays, and is downright terrible. Raw Danger is the perfect fit. What we didn't count on was a love story. How will the Game Informer crew handle this? I won't ruin the surprise for you, but they get emotional, and even share their feelings with each other during the slower moments.

Sit back and enjoy the show, everyone. I think you'll dig this Super Replay. And not to spoil the future, but we're rolling right into another Super Replay of a bad game as soon as this one finishes! New episodes air every Thursday and Sunday.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Soul Blazer: All Episodes
gameInformerArticle.author: Daniel Tack
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
In this Super Replay, we tackle a lesser known SNES classic – Soul Blazer. Developed by Quintet and published by Enix, the action-RPG tasks the player with recovering lost souls after a deal with the evil being Deathtoll goes wrong. Remember Actraiser? There's some inspiration from that title in this first game of a trilogy, with the more recognizable Illusion of Gaia and Terranigma following up Soul Blazer.

With Dan Tack piloting, this Super Replay features Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Kimberly Wallace, and Jeff Cork as they move from world to world recovering Souls and discussing Indiana Jones, Netflix, various colors, and lethal squirrels. For this Super Replay, all episodes are available immediately, so there's no waiting if you want to push through the entire epic playthrough in a single go!

Click on the banner if you prefer to watch this Super Replay on YouTube instead of the video player below.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Resident Evil Code: Veronica
gameInformerArticle.author: Tim Turi
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Earlier this year we relived the Mansion Incident by simultaneously playing through both the 1996 and 2002 versions of Resident Evil. Months later we're still retreading the series' past, this time with the HD remake of the 2000 Dreamcast title Resident Evil Code: Veronica. We're joined by a special guest from Capcom as we return to Claire Redfield's second adventure, which shares surprising parallels with her new starring role in Resident Evil Revelations 2 (check out our cover story reveal).

Both Code: Veronica and Revelations 2 begin with Claire waking up on a remote prison island, locked away in a dirty prison cell. Resident Evil Revelations 2 producer Michiteru Okabe also says Revelations 2 has a strong focus on family - a powerful theme running throughout Code: Veronica as well. That's only the beginning of the many similarities we spot throughout our tense playthrough of one of Resident Evil's most punishing, lengthy entries.

Join Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, Kim Wallace, myself, and special guest Capcom community manager Brett Elston (check out Capcom-Unity here!) as we return to Rockfort Island.

For more exclusive Resident Evil coverage, be sure to visit our cover story hub. For more episodes of Replay, click the banner below.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Resident Evil
gameInformerArticle.author: Tim Turi
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Today marks the 20th anniversary of Capcom's illustrious survival horror series, Resident Evil. Celebrate the occasion by returning to Raccoon City with us in our side-by-side Super Replay of the original Resident Evil on PlayStation, and the much-lauded remake that launched on GameCube in 2002.

Note: This article was originally published on July 24, 2014, which was 16 years after the in-game events of the original Resident Evil.

Today marks the 16th anniversary of the infamous Spencer Mansion incident. On July 24, 1998, members of the Raccoon City Police Department's S.T.A.R.S. Alpha Team entered a biohazardous, trap-filled mansion nestled in a dense forest of the Arklay Mountains. Many of the RPD's finest died battling the biological abominations roaming the huge estate's dusty halls. To commemorate this important chapter in the Resident Evil series and the horror genre, we're revisiting both the original 1996 PlayStation version of Resident Evil, as well as the excellent 2002 GameCube remake.

For this Super Replay, we'll be switching off between the two versions of the game beginning with the PlayStation original. Each subsequent episode will switch back and forth between the two versions. If you're new to the series, expect a lot of cautious crawling through the monster-infested mansion, careful conservation of ammo and health, and chunks of backtracking to unlock new areas. And as with every playthrough of a Resident Evil game, there are bound to be surprises and close calls that rattle even experienced zombie hunters like us.

Join Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Ben Reeves, Kim Wallace, and me as we compare the two iterations of this groundbreaking horror game back-to-back. Will our extensive experience with both versions make these dual playthroughs a cakewalk, or will the varying traps, enemy encounters, and puzzles throw us off and leave us cowering in a corner with half a clip of handgun ammo and a single red herb?

Watch us embark on the harrowing journey below, and tune in every Thursday and Sunday for new episodes. Check out the latest episode below or catch up with all of the episodes with the video player at the bottom of the page.

You can also watch the full series on YouTube right here.

Update: We don't usually release our blooper videos, but we made it a good way into this episode and figured we would share this bonus 15 episode of our Resident Evil Super Replay with all of you. Our original plan was to play through the Resident Evil Zero missions in Resident Evil: Umbrella Chronicles. We made it roughly halfway through recording before our Wii died. Here's all of the footage from that recording. We've included the Wii death.

Check out more episodes at our Replay hub, including our Super Replay of Resident Evil 2.

description: Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks is the featured game of the 23rd installment of Super Replay. It premiered on March 22, 2014 and ended on April 20, 2014. Andrew Reiner and Dan Ryckery host and play cooperatively. This is the only official Super Replay to date played cooperatively, and the only installment with only two hosts.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks
gameInformerArticle.author: Dan Ryckert
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
If you're a longtime fan of Replay, you probably know that Reiner and I are both huge Mortal Kombat fans. Almost three years ago, we revisted Mortal Kombat: Shaolin Monks and were reminded that it's super awesome. We've been talking recently about how it would be fun to do a co-op Super Replay, so what better candidate for our first than Liu Kang and Kung Lao's fatality-filled adventure?

Watch our full playthrough of the game below, and there's no goober skipping the awesome first cutscene this time!

Check out more episodes at our Replay hub.

description: Illbleed was the featured game in the twenty-second installment of Super Replay. It premiered on December 30, 2013 and continues the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games; despite being released a day early.  It featured Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, and Dan Ryckert. It was created by Crazy Games (formerly known as Climax Graphics) the developers of the fifteenth Super Replay installment Blue Stinger.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Illbleed
gameInformerArticle.author: Andrew Reiner
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Game Informer's fourth annual December 31 Super Replay is upon us. We selected a game that many of you have been asking for ever since we finished Blue Stinger. Illbleed shares the same developer, console, and tasty beverages as last year's Super Replay choice. From what we hear, you may even see a familiar face returning.

Despite it's similarities to Blue Stinger, Illbleed's gameplay promises to be a different beast altogether. From our brief look at this title in a Replay Roulette, we don't know what to expect from this odd title. We hope Tim Turi, our designated player of games most people don't want to touch, keeps his sanity through Illbleed's house of horrors.

New episodes of our Illbleed Super Replay air every Saturday and Sunday at 12 PM CT.

Check out more episodes at our Replay hub.

description: Cyberia 2 was the featured game in the twenty-first installment of Super Replay. It premiered on November 16, 2013. It was hosted by Andrew Reiner, Tim Turi, Jeff Cork, Dan Ryckert, and Zach Pligge. It is the sequel to the thirteenth Super Replay installment Cyberia, a game made famous for just how much it frustrated Tim Turi.

The sequel improved almost nothing, and in some cases was actually worse than its predecessor. Although Tim still considers the original Cyberia to be the worst game he has ever beaten (which the crew was surprised with, as it looked to them like Cyberia 2 was worse), he was still quite frustrated by this game as well for very similar reasons, asking out loud in the second episode, "How does it suck so bad in so many similar ways to the original? How did they learn nothing!?" Dan Ryckert agreed, stating, "If you didn't have a walkthrough, this game would be unbeatable."

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Cyberia 2: Resurrection
gameInformerArticle.author: Tim Turi
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
I don't know how it happened, but here we are again. Cyberia is the worst game that I've ever beaten (watch our Super Replay to see for yourself), and somehow the Replay crew has cornered me into playing its god awful sequel. How did that ever get greenlit? I didn't even want to write this post describing how anyone who enjoyed laughing at/along with us during the original Cyberia Super Replay is going to want to tune in. Does it play better? Is it shorter? Is the dastardly "Mike" lurking in the shadows? There's only one way to find out, and that's to dive into Cyberia 2 alongside us.

Cyberia 2: Resurrection released for the PC in 1995, which means the primary controls are mouse and keyboard. This is a most welcome change of pace from the original, which we played 90 percent of with a PlayStation controller. Using the d-pad to play Cyberia's fast-paced, terribly designed shooter sections made some sections nearly impossible. But does using a mouse and keyboard out of the gate in Cyberia 2 make it a cakewalk by comparison? Strap in for what's sure to be an excruciating experience with Dan Ryckert, Jeff Cork, Andrew Reiner, and myself to find out. A very special guest joins us for the first episode: long-time GI community member Zachary Pligge (PliggeTheFallen). Zach was in town to graciously help with our Extra Life 2013 marathon and we invited him on to help kick things off.

Note: New episodes of the Cyberia 2: Resurrection Super Replay will air on Saturdays and Sundays until completion.

For more episodes of Replay and Super Replay, visit our hub.

description: Psychonauts was the featured game in the twentieth installment of Super Replay. It premiered on September 8, 2013. It was hosted by Andrew Reiner, Jeff Cork, Ben Reeves, Jason Oestreicher, Tim Turi and Dan Ryckert.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Psychonauts
gameInformerArticle.author: Jeff Cork
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Talk to anyone who's played through Psychonauts, and you're bound to hear one of two things: "That game was awesome!" or "The meat circus can go #@% itself!"

Majesco released Double Fine's game in 2005 on the Xbox, with a port coming shortly afterward on the PlayStation 2. One of my favorite parts of the game is how each of the levels – which take place in another individual's mind – are cosmetically unique from each other. Some offer completely different gameplay, too, which I won't spoil here for people unfamiliar to the series. All you need to know is that Psychonauts is awesome, and the meat circus isn't really all that bad. 

As always, we'll be updating this Super Replay on Sundays and Thursdays until the end credits roll. Let us know what you think in the comments!

Check out more episodes at our Replay hub.

description: Trapt was the featured game in the nineteenth installment of Super Replay. It premiered on June 30, 2013. It was hosted by Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, Jeff Cork, and Kimberley Wallace.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Trapt
gameInformerArticle.author: Dan Ryckert
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Some longtime gamers may have memories of the Tecmo's Deception series, but not many recall its Playstation 2 entry Trapt. When Reiner showed me the box and told me it would be a good Super Replay candidate, I honestly had no idea what it was. By the end of the first episode, I realized that I was in for a novel experience involving torturing dozens of foes as they attempted to invade my castle.

We'll be updating this Super Replay on Sundays and Thursdays until Trapt is complete. Watch below and let us know your thoughts in the comments!

Check out more episodes at our Replay hub.

description: Ninja Gaiden was the featured game of the eighteenth installment of Super Replay. It ran from April 11, 2013 to April 21, 2013. It was hosted by Jeff Marchiafava, Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert and Bryan Vore.
Episode 1Episode 2Episode 3Episode 4

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay: Ninja Gaiden
gameInformerArticle.author: Jeff Marchiafava
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
This year's Super Replay Showdown ended with an unexpected dance-off between Ben Reeves and I. Even more unexpected was my fleet-footed rise to victory, but my triumph comes at a terrible toll; I now have to grind my way through the original NES installment of Ninja Gaiden, an infuriatingly challenging platformer whose unrelenting annoyances are matched only by the stupid cackling of GI's resident clown, Dan Ryckert.

Will I be able to overcome the multistage boss battle waiting for us at the end of Ninja Gaiden's long and treacherous road? Will I be able to resist the constant urge to bludgeon Dan to death with my microphone? We can only take it one episode at a time, but I'm putting the odds for both at 50/50.

Join Andrew Reiner, Bryan Vore, Dan Ryckert, and I for the inaugural episode of what may very well be the first never-ending Super Replay. 

Check out more episodes at our Replay hub.

description: Dynamite Cop was the featured game in the seventeenth installment of Super Replay. It premiered on March 24, 2013 and ended on March 31, 2013. It was hosted by Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, Jeff Cork, and Ben Reeves. It is the shortest Super Replay to date.
Episode 1
Episode 2
Episode 3

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Dynamite Cop
gameInformerArticle.author: Dan Ryckert
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
On March 6, Andrew Reiner, Ben Reeves, and myself made our weekly visit to the Vault to pick a game to play for Replay. Reiner knelt down by the GameCube wall, Ben Reeves scoured our PSone shelves, and I looked over our Dreamcast selection. Near the top was a game that I had never heard of, but instantly knew I wanted to play. Right on the cover was the line "It's tuna-slinging, hairspray-aiming killer commandos to the rescue!" I wasn't exactly sure what that meant, but it sounded awesome.

Then we put it in. I instantly fell in love with the chaos that unfolded as we pummeled enemies with lawn chairs, nuclear missiles, and plates of sushi rolls. In a first for Replay, what was supposed to be a single episode of the standard show morphed into our new Super Replay. Watch below to learn why we are all of a sudden big fans of Dynamite Cop.

Check out more episodes at our Replay hub.

description: Luigi's Mansion was the featured game in the sixteenth installment of Game Informer's Super Replay series. It ran from February 24, 2013 to March 17, 2013. It was hosted by Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Jeff Cork. Tim also played the game.
history: Luigi's Mansion was the subject of a regular replay before becoming a full super replay.
episodes: The Super Replay of Luigi's Mansion ran for seven episodes with a fixed cast.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay: Luigi's Mansion
gameInformerArticle.author: Tim Turi
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Game Informer's Replay crew has played a ton of crappy games. First there was Overblood, then Galerians, then Overblood 2, then Cyberia, and we just finished up Blue Stinger. While these games are unforgivably awful, I wouldn't trade my time with them for anything. From the statue falling on Raz Karcy in the first hours of Overblood to Dogs Bower's jean shorts, we've shared a lot of good memories with the Replay community. However, I've been jumping on the proverbial grenade by playing all of these stinkers to completion. To reward my gaming martyrdom, the rest of the crew let me choose a game I thought might actually be fun to play. What a novel idea. I chose Luigi's Mansion.

The fact that this Super Replay lines up with the 3DS sequel, Luigi's Mansion: Dark Moon (out March 24), is just a happy coincidence. I missed out on the first game when I got a GameCube, instead focusing on Super Smash Bros. Melee and Rogue Squadron II: Red Leader. In the following years I learned I missed out on some quirky, ghost-busting fun. Recent hands-on time with the 3DS sequel further solidified the fact that I needed to play this game. So here were are, huddled around a purple Nintendo console, ready to beat the sucker.

Join Dan Ryckert, Jeff Cork, Andrew Reiner, and me as we don the green cap of Mario's brother to celebrate Nintendo's official Year of Luigi with Luigi's Mansion.

For more Replay and Super Replay episodes, check out our hub.

description: Blue Stinger is the featured game of the fifteenth Super Replay. Blue Stinger was first discovered as the Replay Roulette in the Sonic Adventure Replay. It premiered on December 31, 2012 and ended on February 14, 2013. It's the third Super Replay to continue the 12/31 tradition of playing terrible games (after OverBlood and OverBlood 2). The editors decided on this game and its premier date on the spot during Episode 17 of the OverBlood 2 Super Replay.
Episode 1Episode 2Episode 3Episode 4Episode 5Episode 6Episode 7Episode 8Episode 9Episode 10Episode 11Episode 12Episode 13Episode 14Bonus Episode

external_links.title: Super Replay T-Shirt Design Winners: Blue Stinger

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay – Blue Stinger
gameInformerArticle.author: Andrew Reiner
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
Over the last couple of years, the Replay crew has introduced a new installment of Super Replay on New Year's Eve. We continue this tradition this year with a game we hope captures the same spirit of the "classic" Overblood games.

Blue Stinger is a survival horror game that launched alongside the Dreamcast in 1999. Join Eliot Blahblahblah and our new best friend Dogs Bower on an amazing trip to Dinosaur Island. Raise a Hassy with Matt Helgeson, Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and I, as we kick off an epic new Super Replay chapter.

description: Mega Man Legends 2 was a Super Replay that ran from September 27, 2012 to November 8, 2012. It was hosted by Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, Tim Turi, and Capcom employee Greg Moore. As with the first MML, Tim Turi was at the controls.
The Super Replay lasted thirteen episodes, one more than Mega Man Legends.

gameInformerArticle.title: Super Replay: Mega Man Legends 2
gameInformerArticle.author: Tim Turi
gameInformerArticle.contentHTML:
We had a ton of fun recording our Super Replay of the first Mega Man Legends. Cans were kicked, ruins were explored, and servbots were swooned over. But let's be honest: That playthrough had its fair share of rough patches. We frequently got lost and I may have accidentally sold all of our best equipment. That's why we teamed up with Capcom and Capcom-Unity for this very special Super Replay of Mega Man Legends 2. Specifically, Greg Moore, Capcom's community liason, hunkered down in the Game Informer office with us for the entire Super Replay. Greg's Mega Man expertise was invaluable, allowing us to have fun and stay on track. Go figure!

We invite you to join our special guest Greg Moore, Andrew Reiner, Dan Ryckert, and myself as we embark on another PlayStation adventure with MegaMan, Roll, and of course, the lovable Data. 

Latest Episode:

Watch more episodes of Replay on our Replay hub.
